Did you notice anything from when you went through in 1969, 1970, and then you fast forward
what, 20 something years?
Was there anything that you said, oh, they got soft over here, they got weak over here,
this is easier or this is harder?
I'm going to say it got harder.
So I take over as a CEO of the center.
And one of the things that I did was I looked at the schedules for each of the different phases.
And I also looked at all the schedules for the advanced training because one of the things
I wanted to do is I wanted to go out and observe the class, observe the instructors,
you got it, yeah, I went and I spent time out at St. Clemente Island when I was the commanding
officer.
I went to wherever there was training.
So I take over as a skipper and I'm looking at the training schedules.
Now when I went through training, I do not recall a training day that started before 0700.
We had to be on the line at 0700.
And I was after breakfast.
So we didn't form up, but training started at 0700.
And I got to training and I'm looking at the schedule.
The 0400, 0400, 0400, 0400, 0400, when I went through it was early.
And this particular thing that jumped out at me was a 0530 or 0515, four mile time run.
And I'm saying, what the hell was this shit?
You know, I was saying that too.
I was doing them.
So whether it was the first phase or the second phase, they came up to me and I said,
what are we doing here?
Well, that's the only low tide.
And that guy is one of the luckiest guys in Naval Special Warfare.
Because my question was, how fucking stupid do I look?
One high tide in the morning?
One low tide in the morning?
One high in the afternoon?
One low in the afternoon.
And that is not cast and stone because there are certain number of days in the year where
you only have, you know, combination of three tides, you know, you'll get two highs.
I said, do not even think about opening your mouth to say anything else about the tides.
But to my point, they were now doing four mile time runs.
And maybe an O-course or another session before breakfast.
And like I say, we didn't do that now.
When we were out at San Clemente Island, there was no schedule.
It was 24 hours a day.
But otherwise, you know, of course, there were night swims.
You know, it was a course when you get, it wasn't like, you know, seven to five every
day.
You might have a night navigation.
We'd go up to different places for orienting and so on.
And again, you throw the clock out the window just because of what you're doing.
But basically, when we were at the Strand, it was a seven to five or seven to five
thirty or again, you talk about night dives and so on.
Of course, you're working until, you know, 10, 11 midnight, whatever it might be.
So it has changed.
They are putting at least 12 or 15 pounds into a 10 pound bag.
I mean, they are really, they're using every minute of the day.
So if somebody asked me, is training hard at the day, you bet your ass it is.
And the kids are in better shape.
They're all in better shape.
So like if you're running with your boat crew, you're running with guys that are able
to run faster.
So you better be able to run faster.
They're just all in better shape.
I was over there a couple of years ago and one of my buddies was now a civilian work
in there.
And we were having the same conversation and we were standing out by the first phase office.
And he, you know, there's a hundred helmets lined up.
And he said, you know, he goes, look at these hundred and whatever it was, 122 helmets.
He goes, every one of these guys I'm telling you was a stud.
And they're gone.
It's like this program is hard.
I said, yeah, Roger that.
It's a hard, freaking program.
